title: Dashboard HTTP server and embedded asset foundation
description:
Set up the foundational HTTP server, routing, and embedded asset infrastructure for the Railyard dashboard.

## What to build
- Create internal/dashboard/ package with:
  - server.go: HTTP server setup, ListenAndServe, graceful shutdown
  - routes.go: route registration (/, /cars, /cars/{id}, /engines, /engines/{id}, /messages, /api/events for SSE)
  - assets/: directory for static files (CSS, HTMX JS library)
  - templates/: directory for Go html/template files
  - embed.go: go:embed directives for assets/ and templates/ directories
- Create cmd/ry/dashboard.go: ry dashboard command
  - --port flag (default 8080)
  - --config/-c flag for railyard.yaml
  - Connects to Dolt DB via config, passes gorm.DB to handlers
  - Prints "Dashboard running at http://localhost:8080" on start
  - Graceful shutdown on SIGINT/SIGTERM

## Routing structure
- GET / — dashboard overview (redirect or serve main page)
- GET /cars — car list with query params (?track=&status=&type=)
- GET /cars/{id} — car detail
- GET /engines — engine list (could be part of dashboard)
- GET /engines/{id} — engine detail
- GET /messages — message list
- GET /api/events — SSE endpoint (implemented in later task, just register route)
- GET /static/* — embedded static assets

## Tech details
- Use Go stdlib net/http with http.ServeMux (Go 1.22+ supports method+path patterns)
- Embed HTMX JS (download htmx.min.js ~14KB into assets/)
- Minimal CSS file in assets/ (can use Pico CSS ~10KB for classless styling or hand-roll)
- Base template layout with nav, content area, and alert placeholder

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] internal/dashboard/ package compiles and exports a Start(opts) function
- [ ] ry dashboard -c railyard.yaml starts HTTP server on configured port
- [ ] GET / returns 200 with HTML containing base layout
- [ ] GET /static/htmx.min.js returns 200 with correct content-type
- [ ] GET /static/style.css returns 200
- [ ] Server shuts down cleanly on SIGINT
- [ ] All routes return 200 (can be placeholder "coming soon" pages initially)
- [ ] Tests: server starts and responds on /, static assets served, unknown routes return 404
- [ ] No external runtime dependencies (all assets embedded)

title: Engine sends done message instead of using ry complete command
description:
## Bug
Engine agent sends a message with subject "car-9921f done" to yardmaster instead of running ry complete <car-id>. Yardmaster logs "unknown subject" and acks it without acting. The car may or may not get marked done depending on whether the engine also ran the correct command.

## Root Cause
Engine instructions in context.go say to use ry car complete but don't strongly warn against messaging for completion. The agent improvises with a message.

## Fix
1. Make engine instructions more explicit: show the command in a code block, add bold warning not to send messages for completion
2. Add a catch in Yardmaster daemon for subjects containing "done" or "complete" — log a clear warning that engines should use ry complete instead

title: Epics not auto-closed after unblocking when all children are merged
description:
## Problem

When an epic has cross-track dependencies (is blocked), and its children all get merged while it's still blocked, the epic is never auto-closed. The sequence:

1. Children get merged via Switch() → TryCloseEpic() is called on the parent epic
2. But the epic is blocked (has its own dependencies), and TryCloseEpic() correctly sets status=done regardless of the epic's own status — it only checks children. However, at this point maybe not all children were done yet.
3. Later, the epic's dependencies resolve → handleBlockedCars() calls UnblockDeps() which transitions the epic from blocked → open
4. But handleBlockedCars() never calls TryCloseEpic() on the newly-unblocked epic
5. The epic sits at status=open with all children merged, never getting auto-closed
6. Engines see it as 'ready' but can't do anything with an epic

## Root cause

Two gaps in the auto-close flow:

1. **handleBlockedCars()** (daemon.go) — unblocks cars via UnblockDeps() but never calls TryCloseEpic() on unblocked epics
2. **Switch()** (switch.go:152-167) — after UnblockDeps(), only calls TryCloseEpic() for the merged car's own parent, not for any epics that were unblocked as cross-track deps

## Fix

1. In handleBlockedCars(): after unblocking a car, if it's an epic, call TryCloseEpic()
2. In Switch(): after UnblockDeps(), iterate the unblocked cars and call TryCloseEpic() on any epics

## Verification
1. go build ./cmd/ry/
2. go test ./internal/yardmaster/ -run TestTryCloseEpic
3. go test ./... -count=1 -timeout 300s -race
close_reason: Added TryCloseEpic() calls after UnblockDeps() in both handleBlockedCars() and Switch(). Epics unblocked via cross-track deps now auto-close when all children are done/merged/cancelled.

title: Railyard Dashboard — Read-only Web UI
description:
Read-only local web dashboard for monitoring Railyard status in real-time. Replaces the need to repeatedly run ry status or watch tmux panes.

## Architecture
- internal/dashboard/ package: HTTP server, handlers, query functions, embedded HTML templates
- cmd/ry/dashboard.go: ry dashboard CLI command (--port flag, default 8080)
- Go html/template for server-rendered pages
- HTMX for live partial-page updates (polling every 3-5s)
- SSE (Server-Sent Events) endpoint for push notifications on human escalations
- All static assets (HTMX JS ~14KB, CSS) embedded via go:embed — ships in the single ry binary

## Pages
1. Dashboard (landing): engines table, track summaries, car counts by status, message queue depth
2. Car list: filterable by track/status/type, links to detail
3. Car detail: all fields, progress history, dependency graph, children
4. Engine detail: status, current car link, recent activity
5. Messages: list with escalation highlighting, priority badges
6. Live updates: HTMX auto-refresh on dashboard sections + SSE alert banner for human escalations

## Design Decisions
- Go templates + HTMX over React SPA: stdlib-first, no build step, embedded in binary
- SSE for escalations over WebSocket: lightweight push, no full duplex needed
- Embedded assets over file serving: single binary, no path issues
- Separate ry dashboard command: keep optional, can integrate into ry start later

## Constraints
- Read-only: no commands or write operations through the UI
- Lightweight: no JS build pipeline, no node dependency
- Local only: localhost, no auth needed
- Data source: same Dolt DB via GORM

title: Fix dispatch to be interactive instead of fire-and-forget
description:
Dispatch currently launches Claude with `-p` flag which makes it a one-shot prompt that processes once and exits. The system prompt says 'Monitor for incoming feature requests' but Claude cannot actually monitor anything — it runs once and the tmux pane goes idle.

The intended purpose (per ARCHITECTURE.md) is that Dispatch is 'the user's primary interface' for decomposing feature requests into beads. This requires an interactive session, not a fire-and-forget.

**Current behavior:** `ry dispatch` runs `claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --system-prompt <prompt> -p <one-shot>` → Claude responds once → process exits → tmux pane idle.

**Desired behavior:** Dispatch should be an interactive Claude session the user can attach to and converse with. Options:
1. Drop the `-p` flag and launch `claude` interactively (user attaches to tmux pane)
2. Use a CLAUDE.md with the dispatch prompt instead of `--system-prompt` so the session has persistent context
3. Potentially use `--stdin` for programmatic interaction

**Files:** `internal/dispatch/dispatch.go`, `internal/dispatch/prompt.go`, `cmd/ry/dispatch.go`
close_reason: Removed -p flag making dispatch interactive. Switched to --append-system-prompt and connected stdin.

title: Auto-update .gitignore based on detected language
description:
Railyard should automatically detect the programming language(s) in use and update the project's .gitignore with appropriate entries for binaries, build artifacts, and other files that should not be pushed to the repo.

**Motivation:** Developers frequently forget to add language-specific ignores (compiled binaries, cache dirs, dependency folders, IDE files, etc.), leading to bloated repos and accidental commits of generated artifacts. Railyard (via Claude Code) can detect the language context and proactively suggest or apply .gitignore updates.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Detect the primary language(s) in the project (e.g., Go, Python, Rust, TypeScript, Java, etc.)
- Maintain a mapping of language -> common ignore patterns (binaries, build output, caches, dependency dirs, IDE files)
- On project init or when new languages are detected, append missing ignore entries to .gitignore
- Do not duplicate entries already present in .gitignore
- Support a dry-run or confirmation mode so users can review proposed changes before applying
- Handle monorepo scenarios where multiple languages coexist

title: ry cocoindex init fails on machines without source tree — docker files not embedded
description:
When running 'ry cocoindex init' on a separate machine where only the ry binary is installed, it fails with:

  Error: start pgvector: open /path/to/project/docker/docker-compose.pgvector.yaml: no such file or directory

The startPGVector() function uses a relative path to docker/docker-compose.pgvector.yaml, but this file only exists in the Railyard source tree. The compose file also volume-mounts ./init-pgvector.sql which also doesn't exist.

**Root cause:** Unlike requirements.txt (which is already embedded via go:embed), the docker compose and init SQL files are not embedded in the binary.

**Fix:** Embed docker-compose.pgvector.yaml and init-pgvector.sql into the binary, write them to the user's project docker/ directory at runtime before running docker compose.

title: Exclude railyard.yaml and orchestration files from engine agent visibility
description:
## Problem

When an engine's Claude Code session searches/reads the project repo, it sees `railyard.yaml` which contains Dolt database connection config (host, port, database name). This confused the agent during a todo app test — it saw the database name and incorporated it into its work instead of building the requested in-memory store.

Engines work in git worktrees (`engines/<engineID>/`) which are checkouts of the same repo, so all repo files including `railyard.yaml` are visible to the Claude Code subprocess.

Other Railyard artifacts that could cause similar confusion:
- `railyard.yaml` — Dolt DB config, track definitions, stall thresholds
- `engines/` directory — other engine worktrees (shouldn't be visible, already gitignored?)
- `.beads/` directory — issue tracking data

## Approach Options

### Option A: .claudeignore in worktree (preferred)
Claude Code respects `.claudeignore` files (same format as `.gitignore`). Before spawning the agent, the engine could write a `.claudeignore` into the worktree that excludes Railyard files:
```
railyard.yaml
.beads/
engines/
```
This is the cleanest solution — the agent never sees the files at all.

Implementation: In `EnsureWorktree()` or `SpawnAgent()` in `internal/engine/git.go` or `internal/engine/subprocess.go`, write the `.claudeignore` file before launching claude.

### Option B: System prompt instruction
Add a line to `writeInstructions()` in `internal/engine/context.go` telling the agent to ignore `railyard.yaml`. Less robust — agents can still stumble on it during file searches.

### Option C: Both
Write `.claudeignore` AND mention it in the prompt for belt-and-suspenders safety.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Engine agents cannot see or search `railyard.yaml` during their work
- [ ] `.claudeignore` is written to the worktree before the Claude Code subprocess starts
- [ ] Excluded files: `railyard.yaml`, `.beads/`, `engines/`
- [ ] The `.claudeignore` is not committed to git (it lives only in the worktree)
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
- [ ] Verify by checking that `buildCommand()` in subprocess.go runs after the ignore file is in place
close_reason: Implemented .claudeignore in worktrees, fixed stall re-claim loop, added engine restart to yardmaster/dispatch prompts

title: ClaimCar serialization failure needs retry loop
description:
## Bug
When two engines on the same track attempt to claim a car simultaneously, one gets a Dolt serialization failure:

    Claim error: Error 1213 (40001): serialization failure: this transaction conflicts with a committed transaction from another client, try restarting transaction

The error is not retried — it propagates up and the engine fails to claim any car that cycle.

## Root Cause
internal/engine/claim.go ClaimCar() uses SELECT ... FOR UPDATE SKIP LOCKED inside a transaction, but Dolt does not fully support row-level SKIP LOCKED (noted in the code comment on line 17). Dolt falls back to transaction serialization, which means concurrent claims on the same car conflict. The losing transaction gets Error 1213, which is a retryable error — Dolt even says "try restarting transaction" in the message — but the code does not retry.

## Fix
Wrap the db.Transaction() call in ClaimCar() in a retry loop (2-3 attempts) with a short random backoff between retries. On Error 1213 (or any MySQL deadlock/serialization error), retry the full transaction. On other errors, return immediately.

This is a standard pattern for databases with optimistic concurrency control.

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] ClaimCar retries on serialization failure (Error 1213) up to 3 times
- [ ] Backoff between retries is short and randomized (e.g., 50-200ms jitter) to avoid thundering herd
- [ ] Non-retryable errors still return immediately
- [ ] After max retries exhausted, return the last error
- [ ] Add a test that verifies the retry logic (can mock/simulate the error)
- [ ] Log a warning on retry so it's visible in engine output
- [ ] Existing ClaimCar tests still pass
close_reason: Added retry loop with jittered backoff (50-200ms) to ClaimCar for Dolt serialization failures (Error 1213). Retries up to 3 times, logs warnings on retry, returns immediately on non-retryable errors.

title: Add draft status for cars to prevent premature engine claiming during planning
description:
## Problem

When Dispatch decomposes a request into multiple cars, it creates them one at a time via `ry car create`. Each car is immediately created with `status=open`. If a car has no dependencies (e.g., a foundation task), an engine can claim it instantly — before Dispatch has finished creating the rest of the plan, setting up dependencies, or adjusting priorities.

This causes problems:
- Engine starts work before the full dependency chain is in place
- If Dispatch adds a dependency AFTER an engine already claimed the car, the dependency is meaningless
- Engine may produce code that conflicts with the plan Dispatch hasn't finished creating
- Race condition: engine claims car → Dispatch adds dep → dep is ignored because car is already claimed

## Solution: Add a `draft` status

Cars should be created in `draft` status instead of `open`. Dispatch creates all cars, sets all dependencies, then explicitly publishes them to `open` when the plan is complete.

### Flow
1. Dispatch creates cars → all start as `status=draft`
2. Dispatch sets dependencies between cars
3. Dispatch reviews the plan with the user (if interactive)
4. Dispatch publishes: `ry car publish <epic-id>` (or `ry car update <id> --status open`)
5. NOW engines can claim them

### Changes Required

#### 1. Car creation (`internal/car/car.go`)
- Change default status from `open` to `draft` in `Create()`
- OR add a `--draft` flag that Dispatch uses (keep backward compat for manual `ry car create`)

#### 2. ClaimCar and ReadyCars queries
- Already filter on `status=open` — draft cars are automatically excluded, no changes needed

#### 3. Add `ry car publish` command (`cmd/ry/car.go`)
- Transitions a car (or all children of an epic) from `draft` to `open`
- `ry car publish <car-id>` — publish single car
- `ry car publish <epic-id> --recursive` — publish epic and all draft children
- Only transitions `draft` → `open`, not other statuses

#### 4. Dispatch prompt (`internal/dispatch/prompt.go`)
- Update workflow to create cars as draft
- Add publish step after all cars and deps are set up
- Show `ry car publish` in available commands

#### 5. Car model (`internal/models/car.go`)
- Document `draft` as a valid status in the model comments

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Cars created by Dispatch start in `draft` status
- [ ] `ry car ready` does not show draft cars
- [ ] Engines cannot claim draft cars (ClaimCar already filters on open)
- [ ] `ry car publish <id>` transitions draft → open
- [ ] `ry car publish <epic-id> --recursive` publishes epic and children
- [ ] `ry car list --status draft` shows unpublished cars
- [ ] Manual `ry car create` still defaults to open (or has `--draft` flag)
- [ ] Dispatch prompt updated with publish workflow
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
close_reason: Added draft status as default for new cars. Cars now start as draft and must be published (draft→open) before engines can claim them. Added Publish() function with recursive support for epics, ry car publish CLI command, updated Dispatch prompt with draft→publish workflow.

title: Engine gets stuck on merge conflicts when starting new car
description:
When an engine finishes one car and picks up a new one, it can hit merge conflicts because the worktree is not cleaned/reset between cars.

## Root Cause

The engine daemon loop (cmd/ry/engine.go:235-240) calls CreateBranch(workDir, claimed.Branch) which does 'git checkout -b <branch> main' — but there is no git fetch, git reset, or worktree cleanup before this. The worktree may have:

1. Dirty working tree from the previous car's uncommitted changes
2. Stale local 'main' ref that doesn't include recent merges from yardmaster
3. Leftover branch checkout from the previous car

## Affected Code

- internal/engine/git.go: EnsureWorktree() creates worktree once at engine start with --detach, but is a no-op on reuse (line 18: just returns existing dir)
- internal/engine/git.go: CreateBranch() does 'git checkout -b <branch> main' without any prior cleanup (line 102)
- cmd/ry/engine.go: daemon loop calls CreateBranch directly after claiming car (line 236) with no fetch/clean step

## Proposed Fix

Add a ResetWorktree(repoDir, engineID) function (or modify the pre-branch flow) that runs before CreateBranch on each new car:

Option A (clean reset - preferred):
  1. git fetch origin (update refs)
  2. git checkout --detach HEAD (detach from any branch)
  3. git clean -fd (remove untracked files)
  4. git reset --hard origin/main (reset to latest main)
  Then CreateBranch proceeds normally from the now-clean, up-to-date state.

Option B (nuke and recreate):
  1. RemoveWorktree(repoDir, engineID)
  2. EnsureWorktree(repoDir, engineID) (creates fresh worktree)
  Simpler but slower — removes/recreates the whole worktree each cycle.

Either way, the key is: the worktree MUST be in a clean state at origin/main before branching for a new car.
close_reason: Added ResetWorktree() function to internal/engine/git.go that runs git fetch, detach, clean, and reset --hard before each new car. Wired into engine daemon loop in cmd/ry/engine.go. 4 new tests all passing.

title: Embed cocoindex Python scripts and migrations in ry binary
description:
## Problem

When `ry cocoindex init` runs on a machine with only the standalone `ry` binary (no source tree), `runMigrations()` fails because `cocoindex/migrate.py` doesn't exist at the relative path. Same issue affects `mcp_server.py`, `main.py`, `config.py`, `overlay.py`, and `build_all.py` which are referenced by engine worktree configs.

Error: `cocoindex/.venv/bin/python: can't open file 'cocoindex/migrate.py': [Errno 2] No such file or directory`

## Solution

Apply the same `//go:embed` pattern used for `requirements.txt` and docker files. Embed all runtime Python files + migration SQL into the `ry` binary and write them to `cocoindex/` on demand.

### Files to embed (runtime only, skip *_test.py)

- `cocoindex/__init__.py`
- `cocoindex/migrate.py`
- `cocoindex/config.py`
- `cocoindex/main.py`
- `cocoindex/build_all.py`
- `cocoindex/overlay.py`
- `cocoindex/mcp_server.py`
- `cocoindex/migrations/001_create_overlay_meta.sql`

### Approach

1. Copy the 7 Python files + 1 migration SQL into `cmd/ry/` with `cocoindex_` prefix naming (e.g. `cocoindex_migrate.py`, `cocoindex_migrations_001.sql`)
2. Add `//go:embed` directives in `cmd/ry/cocoindex.go`
3. Add `ensureCocoIndexScripts(scriptsDir string)` function that writes all files to the project's `cocoindex/` directory (including `cocoindex/migrations/`) if they don't already exist
4. Call `ensureCocoIndexScripts()` from `runCocoIndexInit()` before `runMigrations()` and from any code path that references the scripts
5. Add tests: `TestEnsureCocoIndexScripts_CreatesFiles` and `TestEnsureCocoIndexScripts_SkipsExisting`

### No .env changes needed

- `migrate.py` receives `--database-url` as a CLI argument (set by Go code in `runMigrations()`)
- `mcp_server.py` reads `COCOINDEX_DATABASE_URL` from environment (set by Go code in `WriteMCPConfig()`)
- `config.py` reads `cocoindex.yaml` relative to `__file__` (works once file is on disk)

### Key detail: migrations subdirectory

`migrate.py` uses `os.path.dirname(__file__)` to locate `migrations/` — so the SQL files must be written to `cocoindex/migrations/` for the path resolution to work correctly.

## Verification

1. `go build ./cmd/ry/` — confirms embeds compile
2. `go test ./cmd/ry/ -run TestEnsureCocoIndexScripts` — unit tests pass
3. `go test ./... -count=1 -timeout 300s -race` — full test suite passes
4. Manual: install only the `ry` binary in a clean dir, run `ry cocoindex init`, verify migrate.py runs
close_reason: Embedded all 7 Python scripts + 1 migration SQL into ry binary. Added ensureCocoIndexScripts() called from runCocoIndexInit(). Tests pass.

## Problem

Multiple issues around stalled engine recovery:

1. **Dispatch used `ry start` to restart a stalled engine** — this starts the full orchestration (Dispatch + Yardmaster + engines) instead of restarting just one engine. Dispatch doesn't know about `ry engine restart <engine-id>`.

2. **Yardmaster prompt doesn't include `ry engine restart`** — the yardmaster prompt (`internal/yardmaster/prompt.go`) has a 'Stalled Engine' decision rule that marks engines dead and releases cars, but never restarts them. The command exists (`orchestration.RestartEngine()`) but yardmaster doesn't know about it.

3. **Stale car claims create re-claim loops** — when HandleStall marks a car as 'blocked' and the engine is still alive, the engine daemon's `claimOrReclaim()` (`cmd/ry/engine.go:339`) re-claims it because 'blocked' != 'done'/'cancelled'. The engine loops trying to work on a blocked car forever.

4. **Done cars stuck as claimed** — if a car reaches status 'done' but the engine's `current_car` field wasn't cleared (e.g., process died between completion and cleanup), yardmaster should detect and clean this up so the engine can move on.

5. **Dispatch shouldn't manage engines directly** — engine lifecycle is yardmaster's job. Dispatch should know to describe the problem and let yardmaster handle it, or at most use `ry engine restart`.

## Changes Required

### 1. Yardmaster prompt (`internal/yardmaster/prompt.go`)
- Add `ry engine restart <engine-id>` to Available Commands section
- Update 'Stalled Engine' decision rule: after releasing the car, restart the engine (not just mark dead)
- Add new decision rule 'Stale Car Claim': if car status=done but engine still has it as current_car, clear the claim (`ry car update <id> --assignee ""`)
- Add `ry engine list` and `ry engine restart` to the monitoring loop

### 2. Engine daemon stall recovery (`cmd/ry/engine.go`)
- In the `outcomeStall` case (line 280), after HandleStall, also clear `eng.CurrentCar` and update the DB so the engine doesn't re-claim the blocked car
- In `claimOrReclaim()`, add 'blocked' to the statuses that trigger clearing current_car (alongside 'done' and 'cancelled')

### 3. Dispatch prompt (`internal/dispatch/prompt.go`)
- Add a brief note that engine management (restarts, stall recovery) is yardmaster's responsibility
- If Dispatch needs an engine restarted, it should message yardmaster rather than using `ry start`

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Yardmaster 'Stalled Engine' rule uses restart instead of just marking dead
- [ ] Yardmaster has 'Stale Car Claim' detection rule
- [ ] Engine daemon clears current_car after stall outcome (no re-claim loop)
- [ ] `claimOrReclaim()` treats 'blocked' as a terminal status (clears current_car)
- [ ] Dispatch prompt notes that engine lifecycle = yardmaster responsibility
- [ ] Existing tests still pass

title: Bug: Switch merges branches locally but never pushes main to remote
description:
After the yardmaster merges a completed car's branch into main via Switch() in switch.go, there is no git push to the remote. The gitMerge() function (switch.go:232-249) runs git merge --no-ff but stops there. handleCompletedCars() (daemon.go:273) marks the car as merged and creates a reindex job, but never pushes main.

This means all merges are local-only. In a test project with 8 completed branches, all were merged to main locally but the remote main branch stayed unchanged.

Fix: After a successful merge in gitMerge() (or after Switch() returns with Merged=true), push main to the remote. The push should happen after the merge commit so the remote reflects the new state.

1. Add git push origin main to gitMerge() after the merge succeeds
2. Add a separate gitPush() call in handleCompletedCars after Switch() returns Merged=true
3. Batch pushes — push once after all completed cars are merged in a single daemon cycle (more efficient)

Option 3 is preferred since multiple cars could be merged in the same cycle and a single push is cleaner than pushing after each merge.

title: Exclude epic cars from engine claiming — epics are not implementable work
description:
## Problem

The engine `ClaimCar()` query (`internal/engine/claim.go:36`) and `ReadyCars()` (`internal/car/deps.go:73`) have **no type filter**. They find any car with `status=open` and no unresolved blockers, regardless of type.

This caused a real issue: a frontend track engine picked up an epic car (the only one in ready status). The epic's subtasks were all blocked on backend track work. The engine spawned a Claude Code session that had nothing actionable to do, leading to a stall.

**Epics are container cars** — they group related work but are not directly implementable. An engine should never claim an epic. Epics should auto-close when all their children are done.

### Root Cause
`ClaimCar()` query:
```go
result := tx.Where("status = ? AND (assignee = ? OR assignee IS NULL) AND track = ?", "open", "", track).
    Where("id NOT IN (?)", blockedSub).
    Order("priority ASC, created_at ASC").
    Limit(1).
    Find(&claimed)
```
No `.Where("type != ?", "epic")` clause.

Same for `ReadyCars()`:
```go
q := db.Where("status = ? AND (assignee = ? OR assignee IS NULL)", "open", "").
    Where("id NOT IN (?)", blockedSub)
```

### Related Issue
When an engine claims a car whose children are all blocked on another track, it stalls with nothing to do. Beyond filtering epics, consider: should the engine be able to unclaim a car and move on if it detects the work is blocked? (This relates to railyard-f3r stalled engine recovery.)

## Changes Required

### 1. Filter epics from ClaimCar (`internal/engine/claim.go`)
Add `.Where("type != ?", "epic")` to the claim query so engines never claim epics.

### 2. Filter epics from ReadyCars (`internal/car/deps.go`)
Add the same filter to `ReadyCars()` so `ry car ready` doesn't show epics as claimable.

### 3. Auto-close epics when children complete (`internal/yardmaster/switch.go`)
After `UnblockDeps()` in the Switch flow, check if the merged car's parent is an epic and all siblings are done. If so, auto-close the epic.

### 4. Consider spike type
Spikes (research tasks) ARE implementable — engines should be able to claim them. Only exclude `type=epic`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `ClaimCar()` never returns a car with type=epic
- [ ] `ReadyCars()` never returns a car with type=epic  
- [ ] Add test in `claim_test.go`: epic car with status=open and no deps is NOT claimed
- [ ] Add test in `deps_test.go`: epic doesn't appear in ReadyCars results
- [ ] Epic auto-close: when all children of an epic are done, epic status transitions to done
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
close_reason: Filtered epics from ClaimCar and ReadyCars queries, added TryCloseEpic auto-close after merge, added tests

title: Set engine git identity with user as co-author
description:
When an engine worktree is created or reset, configure per-worktree git identity so commits are attributed to the Railyard engine, with the GitHub user added as co-author.

## Current Behavior

All commits made by engines use the global ~/.gitconfig user.name/user.email (the PAT owner). There is no distinction between human commits and engine commits on GitHub.

## Desired Behavior

Engine commits should show:
  Author: Railyard Engine eng-xxxx <railyard-engine@noreply>
  Co-Authored-By: Username <user@email.com>

Pushes still authenticate via the user's existing PAT — only the commit metadata changes.

## Implementation

1. Add git_user_name and git_user_email fields to railyard.yaml (optional, defaults derived from owner):
   git:
     user_name: ctrower          # or read from global git config
     user_email: ctrower@...     # or read from global git config

2. In EnsureWorktree() or ResetWorktree() (internal/engine/git.go), after worktree setup:
   git config user.name 'Railyard Engine <engineID>'
   git config user.email 'railyard-engine@noreply'

3. In engine context/prompt template, instruct the agent to append:
   Co-Authored-By: <owner_name> <owner_email>
   to all commit messages (similar to how Claude currently adds its own Co-Authored-By).

4. For the yardmaster merge commits (internal/yardmaster/switch.go gitMerge), set
   GIT_AUTHOR_NAME/GIT_COMMITTER_NAME env vars on the exec.Command so merge
   commits also show Railyard attribution.

title: Add real human notification mechanism for escalations
description:
## Problem

Currently yardmaster escalation to humans is just a DB message:
```
ry message send --from yardmaster --to human --subject "escalate" --body "..."
```

This message sits in the Dolt `messages` table until someone manually runs `ry inbox --agent human`. There is no push notification, no terminal alert, no external integration. In practice, the human never sees the escalation unless they're actively polling.

## What's Needed

A notification mechanism that actually reaches the human operator. Options (not mutually exclusive):

### Option A: Terminal notification (minimum viable)
- When yardmaster sends a message to 'human', write to a visible location: tmux status bar, a dedicated tmux pane, or a desktop notification via `notify-send` / `osascript`
- Simplest: yardmaster pane prints a prominent banner that the human sees when they check tmux
- Could also use `tmux display-message` to flash a notification across all panes

### Option B: Webhook integration
- Add optional `notifications` config section in `railyard.yaml`:
```yaml
notifications:
  webhook_url: https://hooks.slack.com/services/...
  # or
  command: "notify-send 'Railyard' '{{.Subject}}: {{.Body}}'"
```
- When a message targets 'human' or has priority 'urgent', fire the webhook/command
- Implementation: `internal/messaging/notify.go` with a `Notify()` function called after `Send()`

### Option C: `ry watch` command
- A blocking command that streams messages to human in real-time
- `ry watch --agent human` — polls inbox and prints new messages as they arrive
- Simpler than webhook, works in any terminal

## Suggested Approach
Start with Option A (tmux display-message) + Option C (`ry watch`). Webhook can come later.

## Files to Modify
- `internal/messaging/send.go` — add notification hook after Send()
- `internal/config/config.go` — add optional NotificationConfig
- `internal/orchestration/orchestration.go` — possibly add a notification pane
- `cmd/ry/` — add `ry watch` command

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] When yardmaster escalates to human, the human gets a visible notification
- [ ] At minimum: tmux display-message shows the escalation text across the session
- [ ] `ry watch --agent human` command streams incoming messages in real-time
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
- [ ] Optional: webhook/command config in railyard.yaml for external notifications
close_reason: Implemented ry watch command + notification hook in messaging.Send()

title: ry engine start fails: missing overlay_table column in engines table
description:
## Problem

Running `ry engine start --config railyard.yaml --track frontend` fails with:
```
Error: register engine: engine: register: Error 1054 (HY000): Unknown column 'overlay_table' in 'engines'
```

The `OverlayTable` field was added to `internal/models/engine.go` as part of the overlay feature, but existing Dolt databases created before that change don't have the column. GORM's `Create()` in `engine.Register()` tries to INSERT into the `overlay_table` column which doesn't exist.

## Root cause

`ry engine start` connects to Dolt (`db.Connect()`) but does NOT run `db.AutoMigrate()` to reconcile the schema. The `ry db init` command does run AutoMigrate, but users don't re-run it after updating the binary.

## Fix

Add `db.AutoMigrate(gormDB)` in `runEngineStart()` (in `cmd/ry/engine.go`) right after the `db.Connect()` call, before any model operations. GORM's AutoMigrate is idempotent — it only adds missing columns/tables and never drops them, so it's safe to run on every startup.

This is the same pattern used in `ry db init` and `ry db reset --reinit`.

### Location
- `cmd/ry/engine.go:83-86` — add `db.AutoMigrate(gormDB)` after `db.Connect()`

## Verification
1. `go build ./cmd/ry/` compiles
2. `go test ./... -count=1 -timeout 300s -race` passes
3. Manual: `ry engine start` succeeds against a Dolt DB that was initialized before the overlay_table column existed
close_reason: Added db.AutoMigrate() call in runEngineStart() after db.Connect() to reconcile schema on startup.
